Muscle Origin Insertion Innervation Action
External oblique
Iliacus Iliac Fossa Lesser Trochanter Femoral n.
L2 - L3		 Hip: Flexion, ER
L/S (UNIL contraction on fixed femur): I/L spine sidebend
L/S (BIL contraction): Raises trunk from supine position
Internal oblique
Psoas Major T12-L4 and associated IV discs
L1-L5 TP		 Lesser Trochanter Lumbar Plexus Direct Br.
L1 - L3		 Hip: Flexion, ER
L/S (unilateral contraction with femur fixed): I/L spine sidebend
L/S (bilateral contraction): Raises trunk from supine position
Psoas Minor T12, L1 vertebrae (lateral aspect) and IVD Pectineal Line
Iliopubic ramus
Iliac fascia
Inguinal ligament		 Spinal nn.
L1 - L3		 Trunk: Weak flexion
Pyramidalis T12 Tenses linea alba
Quadratus lumborum
Rectus abdominis Trunk: Flexion
Abdomen: Compression
Pelvic: stabilization
Transversus abdominis
``` ::: ::: # Anterolateral abdominal wall The 5 paired muscles of the anterolateral abdominal wall can be divided into 2 groups @jonesProjectFoundations2025: ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} ### Anterior vertical muscles - Rectus abdominis @jonesProjectFoundations2025 - Pyramidalis @jonesProjectFoundations2025 ::: ::: {.column} ### Lateral flat muscles - Transverse abdominis - Internal oblique - External oblique ::: ::: # Hollowing All of these muscles are important for flexion and "hollowing" @jonesProjectFoundations2025. Each part of the abdominal wall draws in a different part of the body towards the midline of the (linea alba). The external obliques draw in the ribcage infero-medially. The internal obliques draw the ilium superior medially. the transverse abdominis draws the sides of the body medially. The rectus abdominis pulls the ribcage inferiorly and pelvis superiorly. # Trunk Flexion 2 levers: 1. Pubic symphysis to the sacral promontory 1. Xiphoid to thoracic spine
